Message.Title: MSFT Rally to 33 : Five Catalysts
Message.Msg: 1. A solid, record earnings report on Thursday 24th: Record revenues, Record Profits, Record cash flow. MSFT already said 60Million widows8 sold and that is on top of the ongoing windows7 refresh/upgrade cycle in enterprises. Micrsoft likely sold 1million Surface RT grabbing 5% marketshare of AppleiPad in 2months. Office, Servers, Xbox, Halo, Bing all had solid quarter based data I have seen from industry channel reports 2. Surfce Pro launch next week: I expect Micrsooft will sell between 10Million to 20million Surface Pros in 2013. At an ASP of about $1,000 it will result in $10Billion to $20Billion in additional revenue in 2013. 3. Office2013, Sql and server 2013 as well as the Windows8 at $100 ASP/license (starting Feb 1st) means solid growth I expect about $3.30 forward earnings with a PE of 10 to 13. The stock in my view will rally to 33 soon and then to 42 as the street appreciates the growth prospect. Note: Windows phone is growing 400% year overyearand in some European coutries ishitting 20% marketshare. Microsoft also gets about 1Billion per year android Patent fees and it is growing. New Xbox (720?) will likelybe talked about Feb first week 23c dividend comes in Feb. HP's Bradley says Windows 8 sales arenow accelerating after a slow Holiday season Dell already said Windows 8 sales are strong fro them Lenovo said it is seeing strong demand for touch, Lenovo Yoga like devices Enjoy the ride.

Topic.Title: 3 major innovations with msft

Message.Msg: "Kinect" is Primesense. Microsoft didn't invent it.

Topic.Title: 3 major innovations with msft

Message.Msg: "The depth sensing technology behind Kinect was invented in 2005 by Zeev Zalevsky, Alexander Shpunt, Aviad Maizels and Javier Garcia.[46] Kinect itself was first announced on June 1, 2009 at E3 2009 under the code name "Project Natal".[47] Following in Microsoft's tradition of using cities as code names,[9] "Project Natal" was named after the Brazilian city of Natal as a tribute to the country by Brazilian-born Microsoft director Alex Kipman, who incubated the project.[9][48] The name Natal was also chosen because the word natal means "of or relating to birth", reflecting Microsoft's view of the project as "the birth of the next generation of home entertainment".[36] Three demos were shown to showcase Kinect when it was revealed at Microsoft's E3 2009 Media Briefing: Ricochet, Paint Party and Milo & Kate.[49] A demo based on Burnout Paradise was also shown outside of Microsoft's media briefing.[50] The skeletal mapping technology shown at E3 2009 was capable of simultaneously tracking four people,[34][36][39][48] with a feature extraction of 48 skeletal points on a human body at 30 Hz.[35][48] It was rumored that the launch of Project Natal would be accompanied with the release of a new Xbox 360 console (as either a new retail configuration,[51][52] a significant design revision[53] and/or a modest hardware upgrade[54]). Microsoft dismissed the reports in public and repeatedly emphasized that Project Natal would be fully compatible with all Xbox 360 consoles. Microsoft indicated that the company considers it to be a significant initiative, as fundamental to the Xbox brand as Xbox Live,[55] and with a launch akin to that of a new Xbox console platform.[56] Kinect was even referred to as a "new Xbox" by Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer at a speech for the Executives' Club of Chicago.[57][58] When asked if the introduction will extend the time before the next-generation console platform is launched (historically about 5 years between platforms),[59] Microsoft corpora"

Message.Title: Android dominates mobile market

Topic.Title: They Need To Spin Balmer Off as A Tracker Stock

Message.Msg: Novel idea, but wouldn't really make sense. Ballmer is not in fact separate from the rest of the company, he weighs upon all of it. The other day, I was wondering whether there is any identifiable remnant of Microsoft as it existed before Ballmer became CEO. There were only 19K employees, and the present divisions, set up in preparation for a possible breakup of the company for antitrust reasons, did not exist, or hadn't existed for long.

Topic.Title: Dell - good partner

Message.Msg: In a leveraged-buy-out, much of the cost of buying the company goes on the company balance sheet as new debt. The company largely buys itself. But Dell already has a debt-to-equity ratio of 88. The last thing a box-maker needs is a lot of debt. If there is a plan to reduce debt at a new IPO a few years from now, that would be interesting. But the idea of taking Dell private is a strategy of PC's rebounding a few years from now. And then there is a new IPO during the rebound.
